## Configure Microsoft 365
***
***
***
> AzureAD and MSOnline modules used in this guide have been deprecated in favor of the Microsoft Graph Powershell SDK in Powershell v7. Follow the up-to-date instructions in the documentation or use the updated Microsoft 365 SSO Template to create a new application.
***
***
***
Follow the steps given below to integrate Microsoft as a Single Sign-On (SSO) Service Provider with ${productName} using the SAML 2.0 protocol.
***
***
***
***
> - You need an Office 365 Business account with admin access and a domain added as per the [Microsoft documentation]( https://learn.microsoft.com/en-gb/microsoft-365/admin/setup/add-domain?view=o365-worldwide&redirectSourcePath=%252fen-us%252farticle%252fadd-a-domain-to-office-365-6383f56d-3d09-4dcb-9b41-b5f5a5efd611).
> - Additionally, ensure a Windows instance with PowerShell is installed.
<!--rehype:type=info&title=Prerequisites-->
***
***
***
***
### Install the required modules and connect to Microsoft Azure AD
<!--rehype:numbered=true&content=1-->
***
***
***
Start PowerShell and install the required modules.
***
***
```bash
# Uninstall any existing older version of the AzureAD module
Uninstall-Module AzureAD

Install-Module AzureAD
Install-Module AzureADPreview
Install-Module MSOnline
```
***
***
Log in to Azure AD.
***
***
```bash
Connect-MsolService
```
***
***
Verify domain status.
***
***
```bash
Get-MsolDomain
```
***
***
***
***
### Configure Azure AD Domain Federation
<!--rehype:numbered=true&content=2-->
***
***
***
Configure the domain as a federated domain by providing the respective federation settings that match the ${productName}. Store the federation settings in parameters.
***
***
```bash
$dom="yourdomain.com"
$logonurl="${metadata.saml.ssoUrl}"
$logouturl="${metadata.saml.sloUrl}"
$issueruri="${metadata.saml.issuer}"
$cert="${metadata.saml.certificate}"

Set-MsolDomainAuthentication â€“DomainName $dom -Authentication Federated -PassiveLogOnUri $logonurl -SigningCertificate $cert -IssuerUri $issueruri -LogOffUri $logouturl -PreferredAuthenticationProtocol SAMLP
```
***
***
Verify federation settings.
***
***
```bash
Get-MsolDomainFederationSettings -Domain $dom
```
***
***
If you wish to redo the configurations, run the following command to first move your domain back to the 'Managed' authentication mode.
***
***
```bash
Set-MsolDomainAuthentication -DomainName $dom -Authentication Managed
```
***
***
***
***
### Try Out SSO
<!--rehype:numbered=true&content=3-->
***
***
***
To test the SSO, [create a user](/users) on the ${productName}. Then, add that same user to Microsoft using the following command. Here, the `ImmutableID` should be the UUID of the user.
***
***
```bash
New-MsolUser -UserPrincipalName emailID@yourdomain.com -ImmutableID userID -LastName lastNameOfUser -FirstName firstNameOfUser -DisplayName "Test User"
```
***
***
Alternatively, you can automate the process with [Microsoft Directory Synchronization](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/enterprise/deploy-microsoft-365-directory-synchronization-dirsync-in-microsoft-azure?view=o365-worldwide) or [Azure AD Connect sync](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/hybrid/how-to-connect-sync-whatis).
